CatDescriptText: Elizabeth Harris, housewife, 2459 Waring Court, was part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, June 20, 1959, pg. A1 with question: "In warning against attempting to assure the civil rights of Americans by passing "too many punitive laws," President Eisenhower told the recent National Conference on Civil Rights in Washington, D.C., that: 'I have little faith in ability of statute law to change human hearts to eliminate prejudice. All we can do is hold the line, and wait for a change in mental conditions.'  What do you think of his statement about the problem?" Answer reads: "In my opinion, some people, regardless of laws which are passed, will never treat others in a fair way.  Some of the laws are all right.  However, I see that there is a fundamental change of heart needed and this cannot be brought about by force.  In other words, you can lead a horse to a water trough, but you can't make him drink; you can force a person to get married, but some won't stay married.  You can pass civil rights laws and not secure fair treatment to other."
TitMainTitle: Portrait of Elizabeth Harris wearing light colored button down sleeveless blouse with small brooch and bow at neckline, carrying light colored coat and dark umbrella, standing in front of light colored stone block wall
